name: James Wilson
chief_complaint: Chest pain and shortness of breath

name: Mr. Alcot
chief_complaint: Cough and fever for four days
condition: Community-acquired pneumonia with likely underlying malignancy
symptoms: Productive cough with yellow sputum and blood streaks
Right-sided chest pain that worsens with inspiration
Weight loss of 15 lbs over past few months
physical_exam: Elderly man appearing tired, haggard, and underweight with sallow complexion. Continuous coughing. Leans to right side, holding right chest. Large, non-tender hard lymph node in right supraclavicular fossa. Dullness to percussion in right mid-anterior and mid-lateral lung fields. Bronchial breath sounds, rhonchi, and late inspiratory crackles in the same areas. Bilateral diminished vesicular breath sounds. Finger clubbing present.
history: 50-year smoking history (2 packs/day); chronic smoker's cough for 10-15 years; retired truck driver; history of mild hypertension, bronchitis, appendicitis, hemorrhoids, fractured femur and splenic injury from motorcycle accident
follow_up: After 10 days of antibiotic treatment, fever abated and patient felt somewhat better. Follow-up chest x-ray revealed a right hilar mass. Sputum cytology showed atypical cells.
diagnosis: Community-acquired pneumonia with underlying suspected lung malignancy
imaging_needed: Chest X-ray PA and Lateral views
